I don't think that tech is responsible for hollowing out the middle class. It is true that large tech firms have worked to drive down wages by importing as many H1-b workers as they can bribe our politicians to vote for. It is also true that they have been very aggressive in exporting jobs in the manufacture of iGadgets and computer hardware.

However, tech has also created a lot of stuff which is free to the user. This boosts living standards even if it doesn't show up in GDP. Creating a million copies of software costs the same as creating one copy, so the maximum benefit comes when software is cheap enough for it to be widely used. And the bottom line is that people hate to pay for a good service when they can get a mediocre one for free.

Some tech companies which control key pieces of software infrastructure have indeed gotten very rich, but I don't think this came at the expense of the middle class.

Barry,

If extra testing were so common and doctors were under the impression that they weren't allowed to miss anything, how come they still manage to miss stuff all the time? They do.

Was it last year that I was reading the horror story of the 12 year old boy who was sent home from the ER to die from a blood infection, his parents only realizing how terribly sick he was when it was too late?

Where do you get the idea that Americans get tested so much more than in other countries?

Screening and the issue of false positives are a different issue than the situation where people present with symptoms.

Yes, there are some people who insist on tests and the doctors agree to them, even though they think they aren't necessary, but for every person like that I am willing to bet that there is one who avoids the doctor even though they shouldn't.

My PCP will tell me when he thinks a test is worth doing or not, and if there is a downside, he'll explain what it is.
And unless your physician is a very good diagnostician, and some are better than others, they shouldn't be overly confident in dismissing something concerning a patient.

Nothing can subsitute for good judgement and intuition of a really good doctor or nurse, but the next best thing is having a doctor who knows what he might not know and does not arrogantly dismiss things, and is willing to explain his thinking to the patient.

The invasion of Iraq. at least the 'shock and awe, phase was widely televised and viewed. Perhaps in the future some enterprising entrepreneur will figure a way to broadcast our wars on-demand on cable TV. Millions will pay to watch.

Football is not as dangerous as service in our military. Both are voluntary. At least football players have a chance to make a big paycheck for a little while. Military service is much more heroic but we don't find it entertaining enough to pay either good salaries or adequate compensation for injuries and permanent disabilities.

Another option is to set a federal cap on a corporation's ratio of earnings to US payroll. A fine of 100% would be imposed on any earnings in excess of this amount. To avoid executives from paying the excess to themselves, I would consider only the first $250,000 of an employee's remuneration to be payroll. The cap would be set by analysis of the history of the ratio for that corporation. The federal government has the W2 and earnings filing data to implement this and falsifying these is a criminal act.

This directly addresses the allocation of automation and outsourcing "savings" to stockholders vs. workers. Also executive committee would decide how most effectively to raise payroll for their company. No need to tax and redistribute with fund distribution subject to political whims of government. Also indirectly addresses outsourcing since cap is ratio of earnings to US payroll.

I believe that something along these lines is worth a serious look. We fail to address the growing inequality spawned by rapidly evolving technology at our peril.

Fixing tax injustice is a major key, but state it in a way that is more enlightening and enraging to the masses: END THE WORK PENALTY!

Stop taxing income earned through work more onerously than other income. And stop excluding inheritance receipts from taxable income.

Dick Purcell

Terrific column. Lanier's points about the hollowing out of the middle class by the spread of technology-heavy enterprise and the use of un-paid, user-created content (like this post) are dead accurate.

Like Lanier, I support the idea of a humanistic economy that would increase the pie for the many, as well as for capital providers. This is the economic challenge of the 21st century. As technology displaces labor, one potential solution is to tax capital and the few high-income earners more heavily, in order to create jobs for the displaced.

I look forward to reading (alas, on my Kindle), 'Who Owns the Future?'

congratulation, drollere, you understand how capital accumulation works. i think that all googles and amazons are not producing real values. like financialization. therefore, they are accelerating the decline of capitalism. Now it depends on us...

i admire lanier's impudence; when i was a silicon valley entrepreneur, i once danced with a giant red lobster in his virtual reality lab. it was amusing, but still unrealized commercially.

lanier's theory amounts to saying that all networks are some form of pyramid or ponzi scheme, which can't be right. concentration of wealth is a pathology of structure, not a structural imperative. nor is large network size required to create wealth. networks of conspirators, producers or colluding suppliers profit because the majority of people are excluded.

i'm unconvinced that paying users for their information is a viable economic model. how much is google's use of my personal information in ad targeting worth to me? it can't be worth more than advertisers pay to use it, which is a few pennies. how rich can i get on the perhaps 100 ads shown to my browser in one day? for me that's only $3, or about $1000 per year. but for the 300 million USA internet users, that becomes a $300 billion price tag that either google or the advertisers have to pay.

i get lanier's point that there would be an equilibrium that will pay me and still leave advertising a viable industry, redistributing corporate wealth. but then the payout is going to be much less than $1000 per person. is that really going to salvage the middle class, eliminate economic disparities, create social justice? i don't think lanier has actually done the math.

MarcNYC: Above and beyond your self righteous indignation, your contention is missing substantive support. The legal authority is the US Constitution, which I adequately referenced in my post. Your post failed to refute this. Your argument is that a "practical matter" of the challenges in the implementation of a federal law recognizing gay civil unions warrants changing the definition of the word marriage, and that this situation is therefore constitutional. You base this on the argument that "1100 federal programs and benefits turn on whether a couple is 'married.'" The remainder of your contention is an emotional appeal.

In fact, a federal law recognizing civil unions could very easily state that all federal rights available to married couples are also available to civil union couples. Very simple. Accordingly, your position is without merit.

In regards to your question about how your marriage affects me personally, the question is irrelevant to this debate. Whether an issue personally affects citizens is not a prerequisite to express an opinion that differs from yours. In fact, with little thought, I am confident you can identify the hypocrisy inherent in your question. How horrible it would be for minorities and poor people, for example, if we applied your standard of being affected "personally." For a man arguing for tolerance, you may consider the possibility that your cause would be better served by starting with tolerance in your own home.
RobertC this is no victory for repression, or as you call it: Tradition. This is a minor legal bump on the road to equality for all.

Don't hold your breath. Have you not seen gay parents with children? And, certainly, the divorce rates of heterosexual couples are nothing to brag about. And what about all those heterosexual couples who are sterile and adopt or have in vitro fertilization or have surrogates? Should we not allow them to marry? They're not following your "guidelines" of official approval to use their own genes.  Or what about same sex couples who simply do not choose to have children? Or what about widows and widowers who are beyond the age of childbearing - do we tell them to just "shack up"?

And what about heterosexual couples who are having fertility problems?  Should their marriage be voided?  Marriage means different things to different people.  Why do you limit its function to procreation?
For clarification: are you the John Howard associated with the UFC?

All same sex marriages in the country are going to have to be voided without judgement when Congress gets around to prohibiting same-sex reproduction to avoid having to pay for it. There is no right to do it, or any need to do it, that justifies the cost and risk. Marriage must continue to mean the couple is approved and allowed to conceive offspring together with their own genes.
And you don't see egos being displayed on "your side?"  Do you not see gay as human beings, therefore with rights?
Right. They're really very ordinary beans.

No, actually edamame are soybeans prepared in a particular manner so as to make them edible whole and out of the shell.

It's like lasagna. Lasagna is not just pasta with a gentrified name. The name is meant to tell us more than that.

As I said, they're very common beans, prepared in a very common way.
Edamame or edamame bean is a preparation of immature soybeans in the pod, found in the cuisine of China, Japan and Hawaii. The pods are boiled or steamed and served with salt.
Outside East Asia, the dish is most often found in Japanese restaurants and some Chinese restaurants but it also has found popularity elsewhere as a healthy food item. In the United States it is often sold in bags in the frozen food section of grocery stores.
Edamame are soybeans with a gentrified name

Bwarner wrote: "I believe that homosexuals are my spirit brothers and sisters and deserve the same love and respect as everybody else."

If you feel we shouldn't be allowed to get married, then you don't believe we deserve the same respect.

I find it unfair that many of the comments decrying prejudice also label anybody who would vote against gay marriage as homophobic or extremist. Rarely are their arguments addressed directly, but they are just dismissed with a blanket assumption that anybody making those arguments must be a bigot.

I believe that homosexuals are my spirit brothers and sisters and deserve the same love and respect as everybody else. At the same time, marriage is not a natural right for homosexuals or heterosexuals. It is a way of using the law to promote an institution that society believes provides a general benefit for the rest of society, in the form of more stable families. If people in the state of Utah believe that traditional marriage improves the well-being of society, they should be allowed to promote it without being forced to also promote gay marriage, which they do not see as providing the same benefit.
